Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), lymphopenia (low lymphocyte count), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and anemia.
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, indicating potential hepatotoxicity or systemic inflammation.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, suggesting possible nephrotoxicity or reduced renal function.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Elevated levels due to cytokine release and systemic inflammation following infusion.
Prothrombin Time (PT) / INR: Prolonged clotting times due to coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
D-dimer: Elevated levels, potentially indicating activation of the coagulation cascade or thrombotic events.
Cytokine Levels (e.g., IL-6, TNF-Î±): Elevated levels due to cytokine release syndrome during or after infusion.
Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Decreased immunoglobulin levels due to depletion of B-cells and plasma cells.
Complement Levels (C3, C4): Decreased complement levels due to immune activation and consumption.
Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive result, potentially indicating immune-mediated hemolysis.
Peripheral Blood Smear: Abnormal findings such as schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) in cases of hemolysis or DIC.
Serum Ferritin: Elevated levels due to systemic inflammation or macrophage activation syndrome.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels, particularly in the context of hemolysis.
Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Calcium,: Abnormal levels, including hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia, related to hemolysis or infusion reactions.
Blood Culture: Potential false-positive results due to transient bacteremia during central line placement or infusion.
